citations.narrative:
The hotwire around a large tree inside the tiger enclosure was not attached to the energizer, the top hotwire at the tiger
back gate had an overgrowth of vines behind it, and the placement of the hotwire at the lion back gate left an
approximately 1.5 ft gap between the hotwire and the high chain link fence. Maintenance of hotwire to ensure safety and
containment of animals is necessary for protection of the animals. The facility must ensure that the hotwire is maintained
in good repair.
The water tanks at the aoudad and fallow deer enclosures included drop in water heaters with electric cords that were not
protected from contact with the animals. Damage to electrical cords by animals may result in injury. The facility must
ensure that equipment used to provide potable water protects the animals from injury.
Plastic screening used to prevent the Lady Ross turacos from going through the larger outer wire of the winter enclosure
was torn and ripped off the wall in two sections of over one ft in length each. Materials used to contain animals must be
maintained in good repair to prevent injury from incidents such as accidental entanglement or ingestion. The facility must
ensure that enclosures are maintained to protect animals.

Two of the giraffe feeders had buildups of diet supplements in the bottom that appeared as hard accretions stuck to the
corners, preventing thorough cleaning of the feeders. Food receptacles must be thoroughly cleaned to prevent
contamination or deterioration of food. The facility must ensure that the feeders are adequately cleaned and sanitized as
necessary to ensure the animals' diet is not affected.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 26 April 2024 (60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection) or
the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your
next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The hotwire around a large tree inside the tiger enclosure was not attached to the energizer, the top hotwire at the tiger 
back gate had an overgrowth of vines behind it, and the placement of the hotwire at the lion back gate left an 
approximately 1.5 ft gap between the hotwire and the high chain link fence. Maintenance of hotwire to ensure safety and 
containment of animals is necessary for protection of the animals. The facility must ensure that the hotwire is maintained 
in good repair.  
 
The water tanks at the aoudad and fallow deer enclosures included drop in water heaters with electric cords that were not 
protected from contact with the animals. Damage to electrical cords by animals may result in injury. The facility must 
ensure that equipment used to provide potable water protects the animals from injury.  
 
Plastic screening used to prevent the Lady Ross turacos from going through the larger outer wire of the winter enclosure 
was torn and ripped off the wall in two sections of over one ft in length each. Materials used to contain animals must be 
maintained in good repair to prevent injury from incidents such as accidental entanglement or ingestion. The facility must 
ensure that enclosures are maintained to protect animals. 
3.129(b) 
   
Feeding. 
Two of the giraffe feeders had buildups of diet supplements in the bottom that appeared as hard accretions stuck to the 
corners, preventing thorough cleaning of the feeders. Food receptacles must be thoroughly cleaned to prevent 
contamination or deterioration of food. The facility must ensure that the feeders are adequately cleaned and sanitized as 
necessary to ensure the animals' diet is not affected. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 26 April 2024 (60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection) or 
the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your

next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
